ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned introductory R programming skills as well as several data analysis techniques such regression.
Really broad knowledge of statistics. In the data analysis section we also learned a good bit of R through class, homeworks, and the project.
I learned about basic statistic as well as basic R skills.
I learned the basics of statistics with JDRS and worked on a final project supervised by Prof. Macdonald.
Basic stat knowledge, different statistical distributions, an understanding of stat jargon, a basic familiarity with R

In this class, I learned the basics of programming in R, such as how to create and manipulate data frames to draw insights through multiple regression, correlation matrices, plots, etc.

In S&DS 100, I learned the foundations of statistics, including hypothesis testing, variables, etc. that you would cover in a typical introductory stats course (I had no previous experience and did very well)
I learned basic statistics.
I learned introductory statistics. I also learned Data Analysis through R.
I gained knowledge in basic statistics and I learned how to code in R
Basic statistics. How to use R.
Learn basic stats and basic R
Basics of statistics and a little intro to R
Using R

Introductory statistics skills. We learnt probability theory in the first half and then a more hands on second semester where we were introduced to the R programming language to apply our first semester knowledge.
Basic R skills, overview of statistics
Developed coding skills as well as analytical reasoning skills and problem solving
I developed a basic understanding of a variety of statistical concepts, as well as a basic proficiency with R programming.
a background in statistics and R

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: great professor Weaknesses: Lectures can be a bit dull sometimes

Super fast paced but gives you a good idea of what statistics is and how you can work with it with code. Could be improved by having clearer expectations of what the group project should be, like maybe an actual example of a group project from past students that did well.
It's pretty hands on in terms of learning how to do things in R and applying our statistics knowledge there.

The lectures by JDRS were very well thought out and delivered in an engaging way. The homework enhanced understanding of the course material and the exams were fair. Prof. Macdonald is very proactive in providing assistance to students when working on the final project. He offered multiple office hours and was very responsive to emails. However, I felt that in terms of learning R, I did not learn as much as I hoped for mostly due to time constraints of the course.

This course had a lot of notes and asynchronous instruction which were very helpful for review, but the instruction itself wasnt usually enough for me to fully grasp concepts on its own. The professors and TFs are really helpful though and there are lots of office hours to attend for when youre confused! Those are always immensely useful
Strengths for 106: low-stress way to learn R, problem sets were fair, enjoyed the flexibility offered by final project
It was nice that every class was recorded but that also made it harder for me to go to class.
It moved extremely quickly during the first 8 weeks but the last 5 weeks were more manageable.
I like how they split the course into 8 week sections and I also like the way they made online modules to follow along with.

Strengths: working in groups for final project.
Weakness: too many psets for the first half term.
Maybe give more practice problems for homework so we can get a more solid grasp of the concepts
it's great with online component
This class is a well oiled machine. You learn a lot without any unnecessary extra meetings etc.
I liked the way the course was set up in 2 different halves and breaking up to our specific classes just wish we did it earlier

I really appreciated the recorded online lectures and the flexibility of ways to engage with the content. In order to improve my engagement with the class, I did all the homework assignments in R, in order to make sure I gained proficiency with the course material. I didn't like Minitab very much, and I think ideally R could replace it, though I understand not everyone shares my interest in writing code.
The quizzes and recorded lectures were very helpful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student if he/she interested in learning R or wants to learn a new programming language used for data science.
I would recommend if you want to learn some basic coding in R
If they have never taken statistics before, this is a good class to take because it is an easy way to get introduced to statistics, data science, and R.
Definitely recommend if you haven't taken a stats course before!

I would recommend this course to any Yale student, as statistics is a fundamental life skill/knowledge that everybody should have. The pace of the course in the first seven weeks is very fast, however, and requires significant dedication to fully understand the course material and not fall behind.

Definitely, if you just want a basic intro to stats with a relatively pretty chill workload. Exams are easy (though not too easy, don't disregard studying!) and homeworks are easily doable with office hours!

Yes, this course is low-workload and eases you into the introduction of statistics. if you have previous stats knowledge or want something more intense, this probably isnt the class for you, but if you just want to try out stats and see how you like it then this class would be really good.
I would recommend this course to students who have not used R before and want a low-stress way to learn the basics.
Yes, I thought this class was quite nice that it taught you the basics of statistics without too much work.
I wouldnt if they dont have to take it. The data analysis was great, but introductory stats is not fun to sit through.
Yes, I think it it a great first statistics class, especially if you are interested in data analysis this class will be good for you.
For  freshman, yes.
Easy class and you get a basic intro to R.
Yes if you want to learn statistics or want a review
Yes! Just take it
Yes without a doubt. Whether you are looking to be a stats major or not it is a great place to start.
Yes, it is a good introduction to statistics.
Yes I really enjoyed this class especially the second half
Yes, I thought it was a great introduction to statistics, though I might recommend a class that teaches more R in the first half.
Yes, nice lecture course that splits into more concentrated courses
